title: Hong Kong: NGOs of Citi Community Intern Program Seek Help with Brand-Building and Promotion
summary: Hong Kong – Nearly 60 percent of participating non-governmental agencies (NGOs) in the Citi Community Intern Program seek help on brand-building and promoting their organization, reflecting the growing competition faced by these organizations and the need to build awareness and capacity in the sector. And nearly 200 business students applied for an opportunity to intern at these NGOs and contribute their business knowledge in the area through actual projects.
tag-1: Hong Kong: NGOs of Citi Community Intern Program Seek Help with Brand-Building and Promotion
tag-3: Hong Kong – Nearly 60 percent of participating non-governmental agencies (NGOs) in the Citi Community Intern Program seek help on brand-building and promoting their organization, reflecting the growing competition faced by these organizations and the need to build awareness and capacity in the sector. And nearly 200 business students applied for an opportunity to intern at these NGOs and contribute their business knowledge in the area through actual projects.
tag-4: This is the second year Citi Community Intern Program has been organized, following last year's successful and first-of-its-kind pilot. Similarly, 70 business school students will be placed in 35 local NGOs again to promote the ideals of corporate social responsibility.
tag-5: Organized and sponsored by Citi and co-organized by the Hong Kong Council of Social Service (HKCSS), the innovative program aims to nurture Hong Kong's future business leaders to be more caring and responsible individuals through a broadened understanding of the community's needs and challenges.
tag-6: Shengman Zhang, Citi Country Officer for Hong Kong, said: "We are delighted to see academia, non-profits, and business embrace a cross-sector approach to bring our future business leaders to community organizations for mutual learning that will benefit our community in the long term. It is vitally important for Hong Kong's future business leaders to carry with them an understanding of corporate social responsibility."
tag-7: Kennedy Liu, Chairperson of HKCSS, added: "The Citi Community Intern Program strengthens interns' knowledge of corporate social responsibility. It allows interns to have a better understanding of the underprivileged groups and cultivates interns to become future leaders of the society."
tag-8: The internships will take place between April 2011 to August 2011 and target year-one or -two undergraduates majoring in business studies at Hong Kong universities. The interns will work in pairs to assist their assigned NGO in fundraising and social service programs. This year, students also will be given more in-depth training to further enrich their knowledge of social service development, social issues and a "giving culture" in Hong Kong, which would also serve to make their internships more meaningful.
tag-9: The program provides a total of 20 hours of comprehensive training, including seminars on corporate social responsibility and cross-sector partnerships, visits to non-profits, social enterprises and opportunities to interact with various underprivileged groups, as well as volunteering activities.
tag-10: Participating NGOs represent a broad spectrum of social services, providing support for the elderly, children and youth, and families; offering rehabilitation services; and fulfilling other community needs.
